case_name: Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 134 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd. and M. Sudhir Chandra Guha challenging the Assam Taxation on Goods Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways Act, 1961 (No. 10 of 1961).

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL, JURISDICTION Writ Petiton No. 134 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. K. Niyogi and S.C. Mazumdar, for the petitioners. C. Barua, Advocate-General, Assam, M.C. Setalvad, R.B. Datar and Naunit Lal, for the respondents. S. Pathak, A.N. Sinha and B.N. Ghosh, for the interveners. December 13, 1963. The Judgment of P.B. Gajendragadkar, N. Wanchoo, K.C. Das Gupta and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ. was delivered by Gajendragadkar J. A. K. Sarkar J. delivered a separate Opinion. GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The present writ petition by which the two petitioners Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd., and M. Sudhir Chandra Guha, Manager of the said Company, seek to challenge the validity of the Assam Taxation  On Goods, Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways  Act, 1961  No. 10 of 1961   hereinafter called the Act , is a sequel to the decision of this Court in the case of Atiabari Tea Co., Ltd. v. The State of Assam 1 .

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 is Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd., a company carrying on business of manufacturers, wholesale dealers and exporters of tea at Jalpaiguri, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 25 case is that petitioner No. 1, the companypany, carries on the business of manufacturers wholesale dealers and exporters of tea at Jalpaiguri in the State, of West Bengal. The business of the said garden is managed by petitioner No. 2 and is subject to the companytrol and direction of the companypany. Naturally, the remuneration and prospects of petitioner-No. 2 depend upon the good and economical management and the prosperity of the business of the Company.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 2 is M. Sudhir Chandra Guha, Manager of Petitioner No. 1's tea garden.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 25 case is that petitioner No. 1, the companypany, carries on the business of manufacturers wholesale dealers and exporters of tea at Jalpaiguri in the State, of West Bengal. The business of the said garden is managed by petitioner No. 2 and is subject to the companytrol and direction of the companypany.

facts.text: Company exports tea grown and manufactured in its tea garden by railway from Garopara Railway Station, Jalpaiguri to Calcutta port.

anchor.surface_text: The petition avers that at all material times the companypany exported the tea grown and manufactured by it in its tea garden by Railway from Garopara Railway Station in the district of Jalpaiguri to the Calcutta port. It is companymon ground that Calcutta Port is the principal tea market in the companyntry for sale for companysumption at home as well as for export overseas.

facts.text: Tea journey from Garopara to Calcutta traverses 67 miles through Assam to Dhubri Ghat on River Brahmaputra.

anchor.surface_text: When the tea thus travels from Garopara to Calcutta, it hag to traverse a short distance of about 67 miles through Assam to Dhubri Ghat, on the bank of the River Brahmaputra. It appears that by an arrangement between the Railway and the I.G.N. and R.S.N. Co. Ltd. these goods.

facts.text: Goods transshipped by ferries on inland waterways at Dhubri Ghat to steamers, carried 1.5 to 2 miles to Mankachar through Brahmaputra in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: are taken over by ferries on inland waterways and are transshipped to steamers at the said Ghat. The steamers ,hen carry the goods through the Brahmaputra in Assam up to Mankind the distance between Dhubri Ghat and Mankachar is about 1 1/2 to 2 miles.

facts.text: Steamers cover 572 miles in Pakistan territory before reaching Calcutta Port; total distance 689 miles.

anchor.surface_text: In their journey, the steamers companyer a distance of about 572 miles in Pakistan territory, and then they reach the Calcutta Port. The total distance companyered by the journey of the goods is about 689 miles.

facts.text: Assam Act No. 13 of 1954 received Governor's assent on April 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had, passed a similar Act No. 13 of 1954 which had received the assent of the Governor on the 9th April,, 1954. The validity of the said Act was challenged by the petitioners and certain other producers of tea by filing writ petitions before the Assam High Court.

facts.text: Assam High Court dismissed writ petitions challenging 1954 Act on June 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Assam High Court dismissed the writ petitions and held that the impugned Act of 1954 was valid. The said judgment was pronounced by the High Court on the 6th of June, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court struck down 1954 Act as unconstitutional on September 26, 1960 in Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners whose writ petitions had been dismissed, then preferred appeals to this Court by special leave, and they also, moved this Court by writ petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution. These matters were heard by this Court in the case of Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. 1  and by its judgment delivered on the 26th September, 1960, the said impugned Act was struck down as being unconstitutional.

facts.text: Assam Act 1961 received President's assent on April 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Act with which we are companycerned in, the , present proceedings was passed by the Assam Assembly. It received the assent of the President on the 6th April, 1961.

facts.text: 487 persons filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Assam High Court challenging 1961 Act; allowed on August 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that 487 persons moved the Assam High Court by writ petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution impeaching the validity of the Act. These writ petitions were companysidered.by a Division Bench of the said High Court and they were allowed on the 1st August, 1963.

facts.text: 12 petitioners from Assam HC cases allowed to intervene in present proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent State of Assam then moved the High Court for certificates to enable it to companye to this Court in appeal against the decision of the High Court in the said 487 writ petitions. The High Court has granted certificates, but the said appeals will take long to become ready and so, 12 of the petitioners who are respondents in some of the said appeals were allowed to intervene in the present proceedings.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 13, 1963 by Gajendragadkar J. for majority; separate opinion by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: December 13, 1963. The Judgment of P.B. Gajendragadkar, N. Wanchoo, K.C. Das Gupta and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ. was delivered by Gajendragadkar J. A. K. Sarkar J. delivered a separate Opinion.

facts.text: Act deemed effective from April 24, 1954 to March 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1 3  provides that the Act shall be deemed to have had effect as from the 24th April, 1954, and shall remain in force till the 31st March, 1962.

facts.text: Tax levied on manufactured tea and jute in bales carried by road or inland waterways except railways and airways; realized from producer for tea.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of this Act, there shall be levied a tax on  a  manufactured tea and  b  jute in bales carried by motor vehicle, , cart, trolley, boat, animal and human agency or any other means except railways and airways in such manner and in respect of such period and at such rate as specified in the Schedule.

facts.text: Proviso: Where tea sold at factory premises, producer liable to realize tax from purchaser from notified date.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that where tea is sold at the factory premises, the producer shall be liable for realisation of tax from the purchaser with effect from such date as the Government may, by numberification, appoint, for the carriage of such tea as provided in this section and the producer shall be liable for the payment of such tax numberwithstanding the fact that the tea is number carried by the producer

facts.text: Petitioner company has right to move under Art. 32 conceded by counsel.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 1 is a companypany and as such, it has numberright to move this Court under Art. 32. This position is companyceded by Mr. Mazumdar for the petitioners.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 2 entitled to challenge as citizen threatened by action against company.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 2 who is the Manager of Petitioner No. 1 is, however, a citizen of India and as such, he is entitled to challenge the validity of the Act inasmuch as the respondent threatens to take action in pursuance of the material provisions of the Act against the companypany of which he is the Manager.

facts.text: Assam High Court found Act not compensatory; respondent does not urge compensatory character.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Assam High Court which dealt with the 487 writ petitions has found that the Act is number companypensatory, and Mr. Setalvad has number urged before us that the Act is in fact companypensatory.

facts.text: Among 487 writ petitioners in Assam HC, none was a purchaser; all producers.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the petitioners before us are producers who have carried their own product from their tea gardens to Calcutta, and we were told that amongst the 487 persons who moved the Assam High Court by their writ petitions, number one was a purchaser everyone was a producer who carried his own goods.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds Act's validity; petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the petition fails and is dismissed with companyts.

Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. K. Niyogi and S.C. Mazumdar, for the petitioners. C. Barua, Advocate-General, Assam, M.C. Setalvad, R.B. Datar and Naunit Lal, for the respondents. S. Pathak, A.N. Sinha and B.N. Ghosh, for the interveners. December 13, 1963. The Judgment of P.B. Gajendragadkar, N. Wanchoo, K.C. Das Gupta and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ. was delivered by Gajendragadkar J. A. K. Sarkar J. delivered a separate Opinion. GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The present writ petition by which the two petitioners Khyerbari Tea Co. Ltd., and M. Sudhir Chandra Guha, Manager of the said Company, seek to challenge the validity of the Assam Taxation  On Goods, Carried by Road or on Inland Waterways  Act, 1961  No. 10 of 1961   hereinafter called the Act , is a sequel to the decision of this Court in the case of Atiabari Tea Co., Ltd. v. The State of Assam 1 . To this petition have been impleaded three respondents, the State of Assam, the Commissioner of Taxes, the taxing authority appointed under s. 6 of the Act, and the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri Division. We will refer to the State of Assam as the respondent hereafter.

issues.text: Whether the material provisions of the Act are invalid because the Assam Legislature was not competent to enact them and whether they constitute an unreasonable restriction on the freedom of trade guaranteed by Art. 301 and fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. 2 contends that the material provisions of the Act are invalid, because the Assam Legislature was not competent to enact the said provisions. It is also urged that the said provisions are unconstitutional because they constitute an unreasonable restriction on the freedom of trade guaranteed by Art. 301, as-well-as petitioner No. 2s fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(g) of the Con- stitution.

issues.text: The main question: the tax imposed by the Act not being compensatory in character, are there any reasons to justify the respondents contention that the restrictions imposed by it are reasonable and in the public interest?

anchor.surface_text: The main question, therefore, would be that the tax imposed by the Act not being compensatory in character, are there any reasons to justify the respondents contention that the restrictions imposed by it are reasonable and in the public interest? Let us then consider the broad features of the Act and its material provisions before dealing with the several points urged before us.

issues.text: Whether s. 3 which is the charging section, is outside the legislative competence of the Assam Legislature under Entry 56 List II?

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged before us by Mr. Pathak that s. 3 which is the charging section, is outside the legislative competence of the Assam Legislature. The Act purports to have been passed by virtue of the legislative power conferred on the State Legislature under Entry 56 in List 11 of the Seventh Schedule. This Entry reads thus Taxes on goods and passengers carried by road or on inland waterways.

issues.text: Whether the Act which has been passed under Art. 304(b) can act retrospectively?

anchor.surface_text: Then, Mr. Pathak argues that the Act which has been passed under Art. 304 b cannot act retrospectively. The argument is that when an Act is passed under Art. 304 b after introducing the Bill with the previous sanction of the President, it must always and in every case operate prospectively.

issues.text: What is the question about the onus of proof in these proceedings regarding presumption of constitutionality under Art. 304(b) and Art. 19(6)?

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question about the onus of proof in these proceedings. It may be that in most cases, the question about the onus of proof would turn out to be merely of academic importance, because when one considers the reasonableness of a given

issues.text: Whether the respondent has shown that the restrictions imposed by the Act by levying a tax on the movement of tea can be said to be reasonable and in the public interest?

anchor.surface_text: That naturally takes us to the question as to whether the respondent has shown that the restrictions imposed by the Act by levying a tax on the movement of tea can be said to be reasonable and in the public interest. The decision of this question will inevitably involve the balancing of the importance of freedom of trade as against the requirements of public interest.

issues.text: Whether s. 34 of the Act is unconstitutional as discriminatory and imposing unreasonable restriction under Art. 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak further contended that s. 34 of the Act is unconstitutional inasmuch as it is discriminatory and imposes an unreasonable restriction on the citizens fundamental right to trade under Art. 19(1)(g). We have already cited s. 34. The argument that the restriction imposed by s. 34 is unreasonable, proceeds on the assumption that sub-section (2) prohibits a producer from ventilating his grievance

issues.text: Whether the tax levied by the Act can be said to be discriminatory and unconstitutional under Art. 14 because it selects only tea and jute?
Is the Act extra-territorial in its application?

anchor.surface_text: Is the Act extra-territorial in its application ? That is the next question which calls for an answer, In support of the plea of extra-territoriality, it is urged that the petitioners are all residents of Bengal, that they carry on their tea business in Calcutta, and it is only on the very narrow ground that in its passage from tea garden to Calcutta the tea in question has to cross a distance of a mile and a half in Assam that the tax purports to make the producers from Bengal liable under s. 3(2).

issues.text: Whether the pith and substance of the taxing statute is controlled by the Tea Act passed by the Central Legislature?

anchor.surface_text: The pith and substance of the taxing statute is the levy of a tax on tea, which is carried in the State of Assam and the right to levy such a tax cannot be said to have been taken away merely by the fact that a Tea Act had been passed by the Central Legislature which is referable to the relevant Entry in List 1 of the 7th Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mazumdar has urged before us three subsidiary points in addition to the points argued by Mr. Pathak. He contends that the tax levied by the Act is invalid because a tax

arguments.claim: Tax compensatory/ regulatory outside Art. 301 per Automobile Transport

anchor.surface_text: In the Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. case1, the majority view expressed by Das J. on behalf of himself and Kapur Sarkar JJ was that if a tax is compensatory

arguments.claim: Freedom under Art. 301 subject to direct restrictions; tax complies with 304(b)

anchor.surface_text: On the majority view, if the impugned tax imposes a restriction on the movement of trade, the Act could be sustained if it complied with the provisions of Art. 304(b).

holdings.text: The material provisions of the Act are valid; Assam Legislature competent to enact them under Entry 56 List II; do not constitute unreasonable restriction on Art. 301 or Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged before us by Mr. Pathak that s. 3 which is the charging section, is outside the legislative competence of the Assam Legislature. The Act purports to have been passed by virtue of the legislative power conferred on the State Legislature under Entry 56 in List 11 of the Seventh Schedule. This Entry reads thus Taxes on goods and passengers carried by road or on inland waterways.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxable event is carriage of goods; producer liability has rational nexus due to administrative convenience; Entry 56 widely construed; follows doctrine of nexus and subsidiary machinery powers.

holdings.text: Restrictions imposed by the Act are reasonable and in public interest under Art. 304(b), even though not compensatory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue for roads/waterways maintenance serves public interest; flat rate fair to trade; weighs trade freedom vs public needs; President's sanction indicative; expenditure exceeds revenue.

holdings.text: Section 3, the charging section, is within legislative competence under Entry 56 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The Act purports to have been passed by virtue of the legislative power conferred on the State Legislature under Entry 56 in List 11 of the Seventh Schedule. This Entry reads thus Taxes on goods and passengers carried by road or on inland waterways.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Carriage is taxable event; producer liability rational nexus; administrative convenience; power includes machinery to prevent evasion.

holdings.text: Act passed under Art. 304(b) can operate retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: Then, Mr. Pathak argues that the Act which has been passed under Art. 304 b cannot act retrospectively. The argument is that when an Act is passed under Art. 304 b after introducing the Bill with the previous sanction of the President, it must always and in every case operate prospectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No bar in Art. 304(b); taxing statutes can be retrospective if reasonable; distinguishes prohibition cases; follows prior precedents.

holdings.text: Once invasion of Art. 19(1)(g) or Art. 301 shown, onus shifts to state to prove reasonableness under Art. 19(6)/304(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Saghir Ahmad; presumption rebutted by invasion proof; state must justify exception.

holdings.text: Respondent has shown restrictions by tax on tea movement reasonable and in public interest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances trade freedom vs public revenue needs for infrastructure; flat rate reasonable; state met onus.

holdings.text: Section 34 not unconstitutional as discriminatory or unreasonable under Art. 19(1)(g).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Does not bar appeals/revisions; no invidious distinction; hypothetical, no material facts.

holdings.text: Tax not discriminatory under Art. 14 by selecting only tea and jute.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tea/jute main products; wide legislative latitude in taxation; follows US/Indian precedents on classification.

holdings.text: Act not extra-territorial; sufficient nexus via carriage through Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Is the Act extra-territorial in its application ? That is the next question which calls for an answer, In support of the plea of extra-territoriality, it is urged that the petitioners are all residents of Bengal, that they carry on their tea business in Calcutta, and it is only on the very narrow ground that in its passage from tea garden to Calcutta the tea in question has to cross a distance of a mile and a half in Assam that the tax purports to make the producers from Bengal liable under s. 3(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Physical carriage through Assam provides rational nexus; distance irrelevant; follows Tata Iron doctrine.

holdings.text: Pith and substance of Act is tax on carried goods under Entry 56; not controlled by Tea Act.

anchor.surface_text: The pith and substance of the taxing statute is the levy of a tax 1016 on tea, which is carried in the State of Assam and the right to levy such a tax cannot be said to have been taken away merely by the fact that a Tea Act had been passed by the Central Legislature which is referable to the relevant Entry in List 1 of the 7th Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different purposes; List I no entry controls List II Entry 56; pith and substance doctrine.

holdings.text: Act valid overall; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the petition fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges rejected; upholds Act under Art. 304(b), Entry 56.
